## Commit Message Instructions

Follow Conventional Commits strictly and start with a relevant gitmoji.

Note: Do NOT wrap the final commit message in code fences. Code blocks below are examples only. Commit message statring with ```plaintext is invalid

## Template

<gitmoji> <type>(optional-scope): <short, imperative description>

[optional closed issues]
[optional body]

## Rules

1. Header

- Exactly one gitmoji at the start (see mapping below)
- type is a valid Conventional Commit type in lowercase
- scope is optional; if present, use parentheses: feat(fe), fix(be)
- combine scopes with + (e.g., fe+doc)
- description is imperative, concise, no trailing period
- target â‰² 72 chars total for the header

1. Allowed types

- feat, fix, docs, ci, refactor, perf, test, build, chore, revert, style

1. Allowed scopes

- be, fe, doc, ci â€” or combine with + (e.g., fe+doc)

1. Gitmoji suggestions (pick one that fits best)

- âœ¨ feat
- ğŸ› fix
- ğŸ“ docs

- âª revert
- ğŸ¨ style

1. Closed issues (optional)

- Put on a separate line after the header
- Use "Closes" or "Fixes" to auto-close issues when merged

1. Body (optional, top 3 bullets only)

- Don't include changes in the backend vendor directory
- Use - bullet points
- Include only the most important details (max 3 bullets)
- Max 60 chars per bullet
- Use backticks for code/identifiers when useful

## Checklist for Copilot

- Starts with exactly one appropriate gitmoji
- Uses a valid type and optional scope in parentheses
- Imperative, concise header; no trailing period
- Body â‰¤ 3 bullets, each â‰¤ 60 chars (if present)
- Closed issues line present when relevant (Closes/Fixes #)
